data.title: Conflict: a Distributed Condition: Contemporary War Ecologies
data.desc:
Conflict is not an exception or an isolated event — it is a constant condition running through society. It is not limited to war or explicit clashes: it emerges within collective life as friction, as a continuous confrontation between competing needs, systems, and visions.
It is not a punctual episode but a latent and distributed condition. It takes on asymmetric, often invisible forms, embedded in cultural practices, social relations, and infrastructures. Its logic is not confined to violence: it also structures coexistence, shaping who holds privilege and who is pushed to the margins.
Exploring distributed conflicts means reading the present as a field where techniques of offense multiply and blur into the infrastructures society depends on. The goal is to generate critical devices, scenarios, and questions that probe the ambiguous nature of conflict as a diffuse condition in a post-territorial age.

data.title: Biased Survey
data.desc: Intentionally guiding the interviewee along a path toward a certain answer, or phrased in a way that is confusing, leading to unclear answers.

data.title: Framing Effect
data.desc: Cognitive bias that demonstrates how people's decisions and perceptions are influenced by the way information is presented (or “framed”) rather than by its objective content

data.title: Helthcare and gender bias
data.desc: Gender bias in medical research stems from the historical exclusion of women, the assumption they are just “smaller men,” and poor reporting of sex and gender. This data gap leads to misdiagnosis, inadequate treatments, and a lack of understanding of biological differences across sexes.

data.title: Ranking systems
data.desc: Ranking bias is a form of anchoring bias. It refers to the fact that, in a list of search engine results, people believe that the highest-ranked results are the most relevant and important.

data.title: Mental health stigma
data.desc: While conservatives report much higher mental health ratings, asking instead about general mood eliminated the gap between liberals and conservatives.

data.title: Predictive justice and Algorithmic fairness
data.desc: Several technologies, rather than eliminating conflict, end up reinforcing it. A notable example is the COMPAS software, designed to assist in sentencing decisions, which relied on datasets biased toward a specific ‘type’ of criminal, incorporating factors such as ethnicity and gender. This highlights the challenges faced by the field of algorithmic fairness—an interdisciplinary area that seeks to reduce bias and discrimination in machine learning. Despite its promise, the field lacks a universal definition of fairness and remains controversial, with cases like COMPAS illustrating how models can amplify, rather than mitigate, existing prejudices.

data.title: Psychology's WEIRD Problem
data.desc: Cross-Cultural Perception Studies: Early psychological research relied heavily on WEIRD populations, wrongly generalizing results to all humans and pathologizing non-WEIRD practices. Today, scholars stress the need for culturally sensitive methods to better reflect human diversity.

data.title: Rashmon effect
data.desc: The Rashomon effect is a term derived from the classic 1950 Japanese film Rashomon, which explores the concept of subjective reality and the nature of truth by presenting differing accounts of a single event from the perspectives of multiple characters.

data.title: Goodhart's Law
data.desc: According to Goodhart’s law, when a measure becomes a target it loses its value, as pressure on metrics distorts their meaning. This reduction of reality to what can be measured risks overlooking qualitative and complex aspects such as intentions or values.

data.title: Measuring humans
data.desc: The “metric conflict” arises from trying to reduce emotions and happiness—subjective, nuanced experiences—into objective numbers and scores. While this quantification reassures and allows comparisons, it diminishes the complexity of human experience and can distance us from true happiness.

data.title: Categorizations
data.desc: It is imprinted into our minds that In order to like certain things you also have to look a certain way. People enjoying particular brands or activities, especially with those that are similar, is not an inherently bad thing. It becomes alarming, however, when they start to shift their identities to fit inside a pre-packaged box.

data.title: Solipsism
data.desc: Solipsism is the philosophical doctrine that an individual can be certain only of their own existence, as everything perceived appears external but truly exists only within their own consciousness, making the universe a representation of their mind.

data.title: The data comprehension problem
data.desc: The data comprehension problem arises when even small, simple datasets are inaccessible due to poor presentation. Anderson emphasizes presenting data clearly, shifting the question from “I don’t understand” to “Why isn’t this shown in a way we can understand?” to turn confusion into clarity through meaningful visual organization.

data.title: Deceptive design
data.desc: A dark/deceptive pattern is a user interface intentionally designed to make people take actions they normally wouldn’t or that aren’t in their best interest. It exploits cognitive biases or confusion—like hidden costs, making it easy to join a service but hard to leave, or hiding the “decline” option.

data.title: Misleading statistics
data.desc: Common data misinterpretations include cherry-picking supportive data, confusing correlation with causation, generalizing from small samples, presenting percentages without context, and misreading cumulative probabilities. These errors can lead to misleading or inaccurate conclusions.

data.title: Data Manipulation and Case Studies
data.desc:
The manipulation of data can be observed in the following examples:
1.⁠ ⁠The Mars Climate Orbiter Crash (1999) – Unit Conversion Error
2.⁠ ⁠COVID-19 Data Reporting Variability (2020–2022) – Inconsistent Health Metrics
3.⁠ ⁠Flint Water Crisis Lead Levels (2014–2016) – Sampling and Representation Bias
4.⁠ ⁠Brexit Campaign (2016) – Misleading Data Representation

data.title: datafication
data.desc: The digital quantification of human life—behaviors, relationships, and habits—often to generate economic value. This contemporary phenomenon has significant social consequences, with scholars across disciplines analyzing its intersection of power and knowledge.

data.title: measuring the impossibile
data.desc: “Measuring the Impossible” aims to bridge objectivism and empiricism by combining methods across disciplines to quantify subjective human experiences, from perception to comfort. Selected projects explore consciousness, naturalness, perceptual awareness, and sensory expectations, enhancing understanding and innovation in emerging technologies.

data.title: Theory of relativity
data.desc:
Incompatibility of measurement methods: Two different measurement procedures can yield different results for the same quantity.
Measurement uncertainty: Variations in results for the same quantity arise due to inherent limitations and precision of the measurement process.

data.title: Invisible data on social media
data.desc: “Invisible data” on social media refers to aspects of human experience—like emotions, opinions, and relationships—that aren’t naturally measurable but are quantified through technology or institutional processes. This quantification reduces complexity to numbers, enabling surveillance, control, and social norms while eroding privacy and intimacy.

data.title: Biometric data
data.desc: Wearable technologies track physical metrics like activity, sleep, and heart rate, but these often conflict with perceived mental and emotional well-being, creating a “metric conflict.” While the body is quantified and visible, the mind remains subjective and invisible, and constant self-monitoring can even increase stress and anxiety, ignoring factors like emotions, environment, and relationships.

data.title: Big data
data.desc: The Facebook emotional contagion study sparked debate on Big Data ethics, highlighting tensions between free will and the deterministic growth of scientific knowledge. Big Data research is rapidly expanding, requiring awareness of its contexts, limitations, and unintended social consequences.

data.title: Entertainment
data.desc: The “metric conflict” arises when tragic real-life content, like true crime, is consumed as light entertainment. Quantitative metrics—views, engagement, binge-watching—measure popularity but fail to capture emotional impact or ethical implications, highlighting a growing cultural disconnection from others’ trauma.

data.title: The imposition of measurement systems
data.desc: The imposition of measurement systems has often served political purposes throughout history. Standardized units, clocks, and time zones are not merely tools for coordination—they have been used strategically to assert control over territories, enforce sovereignty, and even resist colonial domination. By regulating how time and measurements are perceived and applied, governments and empires could influence economic activity, social organization, and cultural practices. The historical manipulation of temporal systems illustrates how seemingly neutral standards can carry significant political and social power.

data.title: Wellbeing measurement
data.desc: While we can track nearly every objective aspect of our lives, can we truly measure our well-being? This raises a fundamental tension between maintaining privacy and the continuous monitoring of behaviour.

data.title: Modulor 3.0
data.desc: Le Corbusier's Modulor was conceived as a harmonic system based on the golden ratio, designed to create spaces that were balanced in relation to the "ideal" human. However, the concept of an ideal proportion carries a paradox: real people are not uniform, they do not always fit standard measurements, and, most importantly, they have diverse needs and desires.

data.title: Measurement of Work Value
data.desc: Paying everyone purely based on time or efficiency seems fair at first, but it oversimplifies the complexity of work. True equity requires recognizing the diverse conditions, efforts, and circumstances that shape labor. Ignoring these factors can unintentionally reinforce inequalities rather than eliminate them.

data.title: Time Order
data.desc: Metric and political conflict: the imposition of a single official time can clash with local practices and cultural identities. The conflict can also extend to the individual, as the enforcement of a standardized time for political purposes may conflict with natural biological rhythms.

data.title: Life Check
data.desc: In modern work, man is reduced to biometric data: heartbeat, stress, breaks, micro-expressions monitored by algorithms that ignore the complexity of mental health. Studies on Amazon and the gig economy show how these parameters optimize output but increase anxiety and alienation. Surveillance transforms the worker into an object of control, but at what human cost? Is it really worth sacrificing well-being for performance alone?

data.title: off scale
data.desc: here exists a standard that is perfect only on paper: it is created to simplify, organize, and optimize. But every standard, no matter how precise, is also exclusive. It defines a center and leaves out everything that strays from it. In work, in health, in space, adhering to the standard means conforming to an abstract norm. But who decides what is “perfect”? And what happens to the bodies, minds, and lives that don’t fit into it? Perhaps true balance doesn’t lie in the standard, but in its being questioned.

data.title: Metric Order
data.desc: Measurements are never neutral: every standard hides a power that subordinates local cultures and well-being to state control. The metric system imposed by Napoleon erased centuries of local practices. Today, China adopts a single time zone, causing "social jet lag" and disrupting the biological rhythms of millions of people. But every imposed measure can generate resistance: following one’s own time is an act of rebellion. Whoever controls the measures, controls lives?

data.title: Uses of Biometrics in Conflict
data.desc: Biometric technologies in military conflicts serve multiple purposes: identifying potential threats, controlling access to installations, and supporting targeting operations. These systems help forces distinguish combatants from civilians and deny anonymity to adversaries. However, their deployment raises significant legal concerns under International Humanitarian Law, particularly regarding civilian protection and the principles of distinction and precaution.

data.title: biometric data for workplace surveillance
data.desc: Biometric workplace surveillance encompasses employee monitoring through fingerprint scanners, facial recognition, and wearable devices for attendance tracking and performance evaluation. This technology raises complex issues spanning privacy rights, discrimination risks, implementation challenges, and employee wellbeing impacts across diverse organizational contexts.

data.title: how well biometric systems actually work
data.desc: e gap between biometric technology promises and reality through technical performance analysis, ethical implementation challenges, and real-world deployment outcomes. Despite advanced algorithms and quality measures, practical effectiveness remains limited by infrastructure constraints, user acceptance issues, and institutional capacity gaps in diverse operational environments.

data.title: ethical use of biometric data
data.desc: the unconventional applications of biometric technology that challenge traditional identity frameworks. Papers that push beyond standard biometric authentication uses, exploring how these technologies might serve broader purposes in identity fluidity and post-mortem identification for humanitarian goals.

data.title: benefit of biometric identification systems into workplace management
Time and Motion Study
data.desc:
An engineering methodology aimed at optimizing production processes through the systematic study of the time spent and the methods used to perform work activities. The goal is to improve productivity, reduce waste (muda) and costs, increase the quality of products or services, and ensure ergonomic and safe working conditions.
It is a crucial and controversial metric: for the company, it signals the need for greater speed, while the worker may dispute the standard, arguing that it imposes an excessively demanding pace.

data.title: Neo‑Taylorism and Algorithmic Surveillance
data.desc: The increasing availability of tracking technologies is influencing employers’ decisions about what to monitor and how, often reflecting a modern form of “neo-Taylorism” focused on coercive individual control. A crucial point is that outsourcing measurement through “Surveillance-as-a-Service” (SaaS) leads organizations to rely on superficial and easily quantifiable metrics that may lack real constructive validity, resulting in algorithmic management systems based on weak data. Finally, the author concludes that not even Explainable AI (XAI) can solve the fundamental problem of measuring work, as the intrinsic difficulty of quantifying complex productivity requires an authentic understanding of the workplace that automated systems cannot provide.

data.title: Assessment of Efficiency in Manufacturing/Industries
data.desc: Psychological impacts of lean production systems on worker stress and well‑being are widely studied, while educational and research materials examine human factors assessment methods, competency evaluation in industrial settings, and how workplace organization influences employee performance and mental health.

data.title: Standardization Impact
data.desc: The evolution and impact of standardized measurement systems, tracing their historical development, global adoption patterns, and economic implications. It highlights how universal standards facilitate international trade, scientific collaboration, and technological advancement, while also addressing resistance to change and the continued use of traditional systems in certain regions and contexts.

data.title: Government Standardization
data.desc: Historical government documentation examines metric conversion efforts and standardization processes in military and civilian contexts. Materials address implementation challenges, industry perspectives, and policy coordination for measurement system transitions during the 1980s conversion period.

data.title: Calendar Reforms
data.desc: Revolutionary attempts to restructure temporal measurement systems throughout history, examining how political and scientific movements sought to replace traditional calendars with rationalized alternatives, from decimal-based monthly divisions to astronomical corrections that fundamentally challenged established chronological frameworks and social organization of time.

data.title: calendar imposition from western culture
data.desc: The complex interplay between traditional and modern temporal systems, exploring how different cultures have adapted, maintained, or integrated indigenous calendar systems alongside standardized Western frameworks, while also addressing broader questions of cultural representation and the dynamics between traditional knowledge systems and contemporary global standards

data.title: British Empire and colonies
data.desc:
The British Empire used imperial units of measurement as an "invisible tariff" to economically control its colonies (18th–19th centuries), forcing them to trade exclusively through British channels.
Forced standardization: Colonies had to use pounds, gallons, bushels, yards
Trade isolation: Difficult to trade with metric countries (France, Germany)
Technological dependency: Infrastructure built using imperial standards
Monopoly on conversions: Only London could certify weights and measures

data.title: Brazil Timekeeping
data.desc: Brazil's recent elimination of daylight saving time represents a significant policy shift affecting energy consumption, economic patterns, and daily life rhythms across South America's largest nation.

data.title: daylight saving time and social jet lag
data.desc: Temporal control serves as a powerful political instrument, shaping social order through standardized time zones, work rhythms, and institutional schedules that reflect broader power dynamics and governance strategies.

data.title: bibliography
data.desc:
"The Measure of All Things" di Ken Alder - Racconta la storia della creazione del sistema metrico durante la Rivoluzione Francese, mostrando come la standardizzazione delle misure fosse un progetto politico di modernizzazione e controllo statale.
"Seeing Like a State" di James C. Scott - Un'analisi fondamentale di come gli stati moderni usino la standardizzazione, incluse le unità di misura, per "rendere leggibile" la società e facilitare il controllo amministrativo. Esamina diversi casi storici di imposizione di sistemi uniformi.
"The Power of Maps" di Denis Wood - Pur concentrandosi principalmente sulle mappe, esplora come la cartografia e i sistemi di misurazione spaziale siano strumenti di potere politico e controllo territoriale.
"Metrology and State Formation" di Simon Schaffer (articoli accademici) - Schaffer ha scritto diversi saggi sul rapporto tra metrologia e formazione dello stato moderno.
"Against the Grain" di James C. Scott - Il suo libro più recente che esamina come i primi stati abbiano standardizzato misure, pesi e sistemi di calcolo per facilitare la tassazione e il controllo delle popolazioni.
"The Nothing That Is: A Natural History of Zero" di Robert Kaplan - Sebbene si concentri sullo zero, tocca temi interessanti su come i sistemi numerici e di misurazione riflettano strutture di potere culturali e politiche.

data.title: biorhythms
data.desc: Chronobiology studies internal biological clocks that regulate physiological processes over 24-hour cycles. These circadian rhythms control sleep-wake patterns, hormone production, metabolism, and cellular repair, synchronized by environmental cues like light and temperature.

data.title: Leap Second
data.desc:
The leap second is a second added to UTC time to compensate for the irregular slowing of Earth's rotation. The basic problem:
Atomic time: Atomic clocks are extremely precise and consistent
Astronomical time: Earth's rotation is gradually and irregularly slowing down
Growing discrepancy: Without corrections, clock time would drift away from the actual day/night cycle

data.title: Failure of Le Corbusier's project
data.desc: St. Louis built 33 high-rise towers in 1954 to replace slums. Initially successful, the complex was demolished in 1972 due to crime and decay. Critics blamed modernist architecture, declaring it "the day Modern architecture died." However, the 2011 documentary "The Pruitt-Igoe Myth" shows the real causes were economic collapse, suburbanization, underfunding, and racism—not the design or residents. The architectural failure narrative was a myth that obscured deeper systemic problems.

data.title: Standard makeup project
data.desc: Through visceral body horror and grotesque imagery, the 2024 film critiques society's obsession with youth, beauty standards, and how aging women are rendered invisible. The story explores the violence of beauty culture and the destructive pursuit of physical perfection.

data.title: One size fits all - clothing
data.desc: The pandemic showed that universal advice fails because people face different realities. Some leaders struggled with chaos while others gained free time from eliminating commutes. The same guidance didn't work for both groups. Effective leadership requires matching strategies to individual circumstances rather than following standardized formulas.

data.title: In Praise of One-Size-Fits-All (Politics)
data.desc: From vaccine mandates to minimum wage laws, policies that apply to everyone aren't constraints on freedom—they're how democracies create fairness and protection for all. The phrase, once celebrated in advertising as a symbol of innovation (stretchy fabrics that fit everyone), became a political weapon in the 1980s against collective action. Yet laws, by definition, must "fit all" to be legitimate. This article defends standardization as essential for the common good against neoliberal individualism.

data.title: Systemic Design Bias
data.desc: Research reveals how foundational systems across education, employment, healthcare, technology, and safety infrastructure embed demographic assumptions that create unequal outcomes. From AI algorithms to crash test standards, design choices reflect dominant group characteristics while marginalizing others, perpetuating disparities through seemingly neutral technical specifications and institutional practices.

data.title: The issue
data.desc: The pension system is faltering: the number of people contributing to it is shrinking much faster than the number of those who benefit from it, putting the entire system at risk of collapse. People are retiring later and later, facing the growing conflict between biological aging and the relentless performance demands of the modern workplace.

data.title: Project Blueprint
data.desc: Founder of Braintree and CEO of Kernel Brian Johnson, is an entrepreneur pioneering longevity science through his initiative "Project Blueprint". This ambitious research program applies a data-driven and highly quantified approach to human health, tracking hundreds of biomarkers to measure and optimize biological age. Johnson adheres to a rigorously controlled diet, exercise, and sleep regimen designed to restore youthful function across his organs and systems. His personal experiment in reversing the effects of aging has expanded into a broader movement, "Don’t Die", promoting the pursuit of radical life extension through technology and disciplined self-measurement.

data.title: Unsustainable and Unequal Italian Pension System
data.desc: Italy spends 16% of GDP on pensions (double the OECD average), making it the largest budget item. Workers pay 33% of income in contributions yet pensioners earn more on average than workers—creating a wealth transfer from young to old. Those entering work in 2022 will retire at 71 versus today's 64-year average, receiving lower benefits despite higher contributions. This explains why Italy underspends on education and childcare relative to other countries.

data.title: BioGate Scenario
data.desc: What if retirement were no longer determined by chronological age, but by biological aging instead? Who would be allowed to stop working—and who wouldn’t? Could we define measurable parameters to establish a personalized retirement age?

data.title: Conflict
data.desc:
In this scenario, the obsession with appearing eternally young is reversed—people now strive to appear older. Most people are unable to retire because the parameters are unrealistically strict.
Wealthy individuals, however, can afford to retire because they can pay for procedures to appear older. Retirement is no longer determined by how much you’ve contributed, but by how much you are still able to contribute.

data.title: The Agency - BioAge Bureau
data.desc: The BioAge Bureau subjects individuals to biological age assessments in order to determine their personalized retirement age.

data.title: Conflict dynamics
data.desc:
A full-body scanner measures parameters such as collagen levels, spinal condition, posture, heart health, bone health, and muscle tone. These indicators, analyzed collectively, contribute to determining an individual’s biological aging status.
The first assessment is conducted around age 35, when cellular senescence begins, but it is also performed on individuals who retired earlier than scheduled. If their biological age indicates they are still capable of working, they are required to return to their employment.

data.title: Molecular mechanisms in aging
data.desc: As we age, damaged cells that stop dividing (senescent cells) accumulate in our tissues and release inflammatory molecules that contribute to age-related diseases. Quercetin, a natural compound, can eliminate these senescent fat cells by reducing cellular stress and inflammation. Senescence happens when DNA damage or oxidative stress triggers protective pathways that stop cells from dividing. Various molecular processes control this, including how cells repair DNA and modify their proteins. Two therapeutic approaches are emerging: senolytics (drugs that remove senescent cells) and senomorphics (drugs that reduce their harmful secretions). Both show promise for treating aging-related conditions.

data.desc: Moodboard Biogate Scenario

data.title: Universal Coordinated Time History
data.desc: Before standardized time, every town kept its own local time based on the sun's position, creating chaos for travelers and railways. In 19th century Britain, Plymouth ran 16½ minutes behind Greenwich, forcing travelers to constantly adjust their watches. The railways drove standardization—by 1847, they adopted Greenwich Mean Time for timetables, though local towns resisted this "railway-time aggression" until GMT became legal in 1880. The concept evolved further: in 1884, an international conference established Greenwich as the prime meridian for a "universal day." By 1960, scientists created Coordinated Universal Time (UTC), which combines atomic clock precision with Earth's rotation by adding leap seconds when needed. UTC transformed from a navigator's tool into the global time standard used today.

data.title: Abolishing time zones proposals
data.desc: Arthur C. Clarke and economists Steve Hanke and Dick Henry, have proposed replacing traditional time zones with a single global time using Coordinated Universal Time (UTC). This system, already used by airlines, the military, and the International Space Station, would simplify scheduling, reduce errors in travel and communication, and could offer health benefits by better aligning daily activities with natural circadian rhythms. While local perceptions of day and night would shift, a unified time reflects the global nature of modern society and could make coordination across regions much more efficient.

data.title: China's active challenge to Western-dominated systems
data.desc: China developed BeiDou after the US cut off GPS signals to a Chinese ship in 1993, making it a direct response to Western technological dependence and now surpasses GPS in technical capabilities in many regions. BeiDou is integrated into China's Belt and Road Initiative as a geopolitical tool, with 140+ countries using it and experts warning it could provide China leverage to hold other nations' economies hostage. A US government advisory board stated "GPS's capabilities are now substantially inferior to those of China's BeiDou," acknowledging the shift in technological dominance.

data.title: Historical precedents for meridian competition:
data.desc: At the 1884 International Meridian Conference, France abstained from voting for Greenwich and continued using the Paris meridian for several decades, showing national resistance to accepting another country's standard. Before Greenwich's adoption, different countries had competing meridians through their capitals - Greenwich, Paris, Berlin, and Washington were all candidate.

data.title: Decline of Western hegemony
data.desc:
International affairs are shifting from a unipolar world dominated by the US to a multipolar system where power is more distributed across states, companies, and non-state actors. China and Russia are currently challenging, albeit in different ways, the Western liberal order, with competing visions of how the international order should be run.
China's Belt and Road Initiative and India's Act East Policy are examples of alternative development models that challenge traditional Western-led development models

data.title: Direct challenge to Western logic
data.desc:
In June 2023, BRICS foreign ministers called for a "rebalancing of the global order away from Western nations," stating that "the world is multipolar, that it is rebalancing, and that old ways cannot address new situations". 

In 2023, Prime Minister Modi's government replaced "India" with "Bharat" in G20 dinner invitations, referring to "President of Bharat" instead of "President of India," triggering speculation about an official name change. The BJP has systematically renamed cities with Muslim and colonial names, including changing Allahabad to Prayagraj in 2018 and Aurangabad to Chhatrapati Sambhaji Nagar in 2022.

data.title: The issue
data.desc: Even seemingly objective measurements, such as the definition of time, are influenced by political factors that are far from neutral. The system of time zones is based on an objective physical measurement, yet its implementation is inevitably shaped by political decisions. What appears to be a neutral standard in reality conceals an act of imposition, in which political boundaries often prevail over geographical logic.

data.title: Time Control Scenario
data.desc:
What if there was a single time zone in the world?

In a future where a global time zone is imposed to synchronize the workday with the demands of the global economy, which meridian should define the standard reference?
The Greenwich Meridian, historically chosen due to British colonial dominance, would become obsolete. In today’s geopolitical context, where emerging powers challenge the old Western order, even the choice of a reference time becomes a site of contestation: each country might seek to impose its own temporal standard as a symbol of global influence.
Whoever controls “zero hour” determines when the workday begins, which populations live according to the official circadian rhythms, and which must adapt to sleeping by day and working by night.

data.title: Conflict
data.desc: In the current geopolitical context, where emerging powers are challenging historical Western norms, the choice of the Greenwich meridian could come under scrutiny. States might find themselves competing to impose their own time zone as the global standard. In this scenario, the “supremacy” of a time zone would no longer be determined by historical or geographical factors, but by each country’s influence and significance in the contemporary world.

data.title: The Agency - SYNCRO
data.desc: The International Agency SYNCHRO (Systematic Normalization of Chronometric Rank Organization) evaluates the performance of states using a global ranking system. This system is designed to assess nations based on criteria that differ from traditional Western logic, yet are fundamental in other cultural contexts. For example, it considers indicators of social stability, such as the absence of conflict or the number of days without strikes.

data.title: Conflict dynamics
data.desc: Establishing indicators and assigning weights can become an act of power, where the metrics risk generating conflict as well as resolving it. Even in this seemingly neutral scenario, the decision of which indicators matter most—and how much weight to assign to each—reflects a set of values and is far from neutral. These measurements can become a political instrument, triggering competition among countries to impose their own time zone as a symbolic demonstration of power.

data.title: Reconfiguring the Internet Through the Logic of the Sun
data.desc: The Solar Protocol explores natural rather than artificial intelligence. The work takes the form of a network of solar-powered servers, installed and maintained by volunteers around the world who collectively host the Solar Protocol web platform. This platform is then served to visitors from wherever there is the most sunlight in the network. The project reconfigures Internet protocols according to the logic of the sun, where decisions about where Internet traffic is routed and what content is displayed on the site are automated according to an environmental logic derived from the season, time of day, and weather conditions across the network.

data.title: Case Studies
data.desc: Offset is a carbon registry and online store selling premium, high-quality carbon credits generated from direct action and industrial sabotage. Each credit is represented by a unique certificate, printed with archival ink on photographic rag paper, and the proceeds from every sale are directly donated to the activists responsible for each action. Each case is analyzed and quantified for its carbon benefit using methods borrowed from the carbon accounting industry. Offset asks what an alternative carbon market might look like if it centered on social exchanges and political actions contributing to a program of radical change.

data.title: Cases Studies
data.desc: A series of innovative projects exploring the intersection of technology, data, and environmental issues. These works challenge conventional systems of  measurement, labor, and environmental accountability. They reveal common tactics and artifacts that make contested metrics feel objective, providing ready prototypes and provocations for speculative interventions.

data.title: Xeno Computer 0.1: Labor
data.desc: An experimental installation by Tega Brain and Sam Lavigne that reimagines labor distribution in the United States through a hybrid system of mechanical randomness and digital computation. The setup includes three random digit generators made from air pumps and colored balls, a cluster of Raspberry Pi computers, and a dashboard that visualizes the status and locations of labor assignments. The system selects candidates and job assignments from a pool of 30 million Americans using random numbers generated by the system. The project critiques the mechanization of labor and the abstraction of human work into data, challenging the assumptions underlying contemporary labor markets.

data.title: The Doomsday Clock
data.desc: The Doomsday Clock uses a symbolic countdown to midnight to represent how close humanity is to global catastrophe. Initially set at seven minutes to midnight, it tracks threats from nuclear weapons, climate change, and disruptive technologies. A board of scientists meets twice yearly to adjust the clock based on world events. It reached its closest point—89 seconds to midnight—in January 2025. The clock has moved backward during periods of cooperation, like after the 1963 Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty (12 minutes to midnight) and the 1991 Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty (17 minutes). The Doomsday Clock attempts to quantify existential risk through a simple, urgent visual metaphor.

data.title: Metrics of the Time Control Scenario
data.desc: Specifically, we have thought of indicators of social stability that therefore represent the absence of conflict in a country, for example internal stability such as the number of days without violence or repression.

data.title: Silence culture in Asian communication
data.desc: In Asian cultures, silence holds profound positive meaning rooted in philosophical traditions like Zen Buddhism and Confucianism, where it signifies respect, thoughtfulness, and wisdom. While North Americans typically feel uncomfortable with more than a second of conversational silence, Asians are comfortable with pauses lasting one to two minutes, using silence to demonstrate careful consideration before responding. This cultural practice extends to hierarchical workplace settings, where remaining silent in the presence of authority shows deference and helps maintain face-saving—avoiding public disagreement or embarrassment. In contrast, Western cultures often interpret silence as disengagement, lack of knowledge, or awkwardness, leading to significant cross-cultural miscommunication in business and international settings.Retry

data.title: Stability parameters
data.desc:
- National Silence Quota: Hours per day with noise below 30 decibels; greater silence increases influence.
- Strike-Free Days: Indicates union suppression and limited mobility, not harmony.
- Local Product Dependence: Penalizes reliance on global trade and specialization.
- Days Without Violence or Repression: Reflects stability achieved without force or exceptional laws.
- Potential Resources: Includes untapped minerals, renewable energy, and population under 30 (demographic dividend).
- Surveillance Index: Advanced systems prevent conflict but prioritize security over privacy.
Standardized Dress Codes: Signal order but also strict social control (e.g., Singapore).
- Low Light Pollution: Less night brightness equals better rating.
- Peace Index: Based on the Global Peace Index (GPI).

data.title: The Paradox of the strike
data.desc: Removing the right to strike was supposed to reduce conflict by channeling disputes into a formal process. Instead, it made the process itself dysfunctional. When management knew workers couldn't strike over grievances, they started denying claims that would have previously been resolved, making the grievance system appear more like a tool for stonewalling than solving disputes.

data.title: Light pollution inequities
data.desc: These sources explore how public lighting operates as both a symbol and instrument of urban inequality. They argue that illumination should serve as a means of social inclusion rather than a mechanism of surveillance or a privilege of affluent areas. The unequal distribution of light exposes how urban design embodies and perpetuates assumptions about which communities and residents the city deems worthy.

data.title: Digital surveillance
data.desc: These sources show how digital surveillance operates across political systems, challenging simple democracy-versus-authoritarianism distinctions. Surveillance emerges as a global phenomenon shaped by state capacity, technology, and social trust. Data shows China, India, and Pakistan as the most surveilled nations. While surveillance can suppress creativity in autocracies, it also fuels AI innovation. Democracies, too, practice mass surveillance, with public acceptance shaped by culture and state-society relations.

data.title: Digital authoritarianism
data.desc: Several African governments have embraced digital authoritarianism through aggressive measures that curtail internet freedoms, using digital technologies to surveil, repress and manipulate populations. Surveillance has been digitalized and automated, making mass surveillance possible

data.title: Human Development Index (HDI)
data.desc: The Human Development Index (HDI), challenges GDP-focused development measurement by combining health, education, and living standards into one metric. They emphasize that people and capabilities—not just economic growth—should define national progress. The HDI uses life expectancy, schooling years, and income to create composite scores between 0-1, enabling cross-country comparisons that reveal how nations with similar GNI achieve different human outcomes.

data.title: Standardized appearance codes
data.desc: Standardized appearance codes in schools function as instruments of social control and discipline, often reflecting broader authoritarian structures. Thailand's 50-year haircut regulatio requiring military-style cuts for boys and ear-length bobs for girls, exemplifies extreme enforcement through public humiliation. The sources show tensions between institutional claims of promoting equality and discipline versus students demands for bodily autonomy, self-expression, and human rights, with enforcement often prioritizing conformity over individual freedom.

data.title: Global Peace Index
data.desc: The Global Peace Index (GPI), produced by the Institute for Economics & Peace, ranks 163 countries using 23 indicators across three domains: societal safety, ongoing conflicts, and militarization. The index weighs internal peace at 60% and external peace at 40%. Recent findings show declining global peace, 97 countries deteriorated in 2024, with 162,000 conflict deaths in 2023. Iceland consistently ranks most peaceful, while Afghanistan remains least peaceful.

data.title: Improved Scenario
data.desc:
What if time were an instrument of power?

In this scenario, deciding where to place zero hour becomes once again a question of power. Whoever controls zero hour controls the daily reference point for billions of people. Recent conflicts have shown how temporal manipulation can disorient and dominate. To prevent time from becoming a geopolitical weapon, the United Nations proposes adopting a single time zone that synchronizes the global working day: a solution that requires a transparent and shared regulatory body, capable of balancing operational efficiency with equitable representation among powers.

data.title: Concept Review
data.desc:
The what-if isn't working well. The result of the speculation—that the world has a single time zone—needs to focus more on the conflict of power and temporal control. It should provoke more reflection and be less explicit. 

Draw from the original problem or scenario to formulate valid terms for the what-if.

data.title: Project Review
data.desc:
The project needs two components: a brand narrative with visual elements that immerses people in a credible story about how time zones impose control, and a measurement system combining individual kit readings (like light pollution and silence) with external data to calculate scores. 

The time zone aspect currently feels weak and unexperiential, it needs stronger framing around conflict and power imposition rather than explicit "what if" scenarios. The what-if isn't working well. The result of the speculation, that the world has a single time zone, needs to focus more on the conflict of power and temporal control. It should provoke more reflection and be less explicit. 

The narrative should explain why each parameter was chosen, use a complex formula (not simple addition) for scoring, reference historical contexts beyond Greenwich (like the Gini coefficient for inequality), and create visceral impact through shocking visualizations like maps overlaying time zones with actual sunlight curves. 

The experience must help individuals connect their personal measurements to the broader systemic problem, making the violence of disrupting natural cycles tangible.

data.title: Improving The Issue
data.desc: The Greenwich Meridian, for centuries a reference point and symbol of British hegemony, appears today as a relic of a world that no longer exists. The axis of global power is shifting: from Western unipolarity to a multipolar system in which states, corporations, and non-state actors compete to redefine the rules of the game.

data.title: Improved Scenario
data.desc: In this transition, time itself becomes an object of contention once again. No longer a simple neutral convention, but an instrument of power, time becomes a terrain of symbolic and political struggle. Emerging powers, from China to India, claim the right to establish a new "zero hour," challenging the historical centrality of the West. Establishing where time begins means deciding who sets the rhythm of the world. In an era marked by instability and technological rearmament, the measurement of time transforms into a geopolitical frontier, an invisible yet decisive battlefield.

data.title: SYNCHRO's Role
data.desc:
SYNCHRO (SYstematic Normalization of CHronometric Rank Organization) is an intergovernmental organization tasked with evaluating state performance to determine which country holds the right to define the reference time. Every two years, this system allows for the designation of which nation has the right to impose its time on the rest of the planet.

Among its main objectives are maintaining order, developing relations, and pursuing international cooperation.

data.title: Improved Conflict Dynamics
data.desc:
The ranking is based on parameters of social stability understood as the absence of internal conflict within countries, measuring a set of parameters that monitor the population's adherence to norms and standards. The resulting stability is therefore not the product of cohesion, but of control. 

Parameters were chosen that privilege values impacting multiple levels: from individual well-being to social cohesion on a national scale. The intent is to avoid standard indicators already commonly used, seeking more transversal measures instead. Each parameter has a different weight, defined based on its relevance. 

The system articulates the evaluation of each country's score on two levels: one part derives from individual parameters, measured directly on citizens; the remaining part is determined by comprehensive parameters at the national level. Real-time measurement of a significant individual parameter, focused on the theme of time. The data is then inserted into the formula to calculate the updated position in the ranking and see the variation compared to the current situation.

data.title: Surveillance Technologies
data.desc:
Hats, headbands, or earbuds with wireless electrodes that monitor brain activity to detect levels of attention, stress, anger, anxiety, or sadness.

Systems that identify people by their unique way of walking, analyzing speed, stride length, and joint rotation. They work at a distance without the subject's cooperation.

High-speed cameras (200+ fps) that capture involuntary facial movements lasting 1/15 to 1/25 of a second, revealing emotions that people try to hide.

Emotion recognition systems that monitor changes in tone and pitch indicating anger and frustration.

Sensors that measure body temperature, melatonin, and cortisol to verify how well the biological rhythm adapts to the imposed time zone.

Analysis of the hours during which energy, data, and services are consumed—penalizing activities during "deviant" time slots.

Sensors that detect fatigue or incorrect postures caused by work schedules not synchronized with the natural cycle.

data.title: Individual Parameters
data.desc:

* stress level --> wearable that detects breathing/heartbeat or something that detects skin conductance
* productivity level --> electrodes that measure concentration
* hours dedicated to work vs hours dedicated to leisure time
* level of muscle development --> electrodes
* consumption of water/energy/natural resources --> ring that gets wet when you get wet, ring that detects artificial light exposure
* sleep rhythm --> eye mask
* hair length standard --> scissors/brush
* air quality --> Breathing Collar, detects air quality and time spent in closed vs open environments, to estimate CO₂ footprint
